title: 108_hr5322
content: The Act titled "Managing Our Medicare and Medicaid Services and Protecting Our Parents Act" includes a loan repayment program for nurse practitioners and physician assistants serving in underserved nursing homes. This program is added as section 487H in Title IV of the Public Health Service Act. The "Managing Our Medicare and Medicaid Services and Protecting Our Parents Act" includes a program for nurse practitioners and physician assistants to serve in underserved nursing homes. The program involves contracts with individuals agreeing to serve for at least 3 years in exchange for the Federal Government making payments on their educational loans for up to 5 years. The amount of payment for a year of service is capped at the remaining outstanding loan obligation. The program offers payments on educational loans for nurse practitioners and physician assistants serving in underserved nursing homes for up to 5 years. Payment amounts increase each year of service, and the program follows similar provisions as the National Health Service Corps Loan Repayment Program. The term 'medicaid recipient' refers to a nursing home resident receiving medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The term 'medicare recipient' refers to a skilled nursing home resident receiving benefits under part A of title XVIII of the Social Security Act. A 'nursing home' is defined as an institution or facility for licensing purposes under State law. The term 'underserved nursing home' is defined as a nursing home where at least 85% of residents are medicaid recipients, not more than 8% are medicare recipients, and not more than 10% are neither medicaid nor medicare recipients. Funding for this program is authorized through appropriations for each fiscal year and remains available for two fiscal years after allocation. SEC. 3. Training program for nursing home administrators. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants to States for nursing home administrator mentor programs to improve training and leadership. This includes identifying potential mentors and training them to support administrators in underserved nursing homes. The Public Health Service Act authorizes grants for nursing home administrator mentor programs. States must submit applications to the Secretary for funding. $25,000,000 is authorized for this purpose. Definitions for "nursing home" and "nursing home administrator" are provided in the section. The term "nursing home administrator" refers to an individual responsible for the general administration of a nursing home, regardless of ownership or shared duties. The term "State" is defined as per title XIX of the Social Security Act. SEC. 4. HIGH FAMILY INVOLVEMENT IN NURSING HOMES. The Director of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services will include family involvement as a quality indicator in nursing home evaluations. SEC. 5. REINSTITUTION OF BOREN AMENDMENT MEDICAID PAYMENT METHODOLOGY. SEC. 5. REINSTITUTION OF BOREN AMENDMENT MEDICAID PAYMENT METHODOLOGY. Amends Section 1902(a)(13) of the Social Security Act to provide for payment of services through rates determined as of August 1, 1997. Allows the Secretary to establish safe harbor rates for compliance. Effective one year after enactment. SEC. 6. INCREASE OF MEDICAID FMAP. Amends Section 1905(b) of the Social Security Act to increase the Federal medical assistance percentage by 2 percentage points for states with less than 60 percent, and by 1 percentage point for states with 60 percent or greater, starting from October 1, 2004.
